channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel’s Parliament Draws a Line on Short Hemlines
item.description: Dozens of female employees arrived at the Knesset in above-the-knee outfits to protest what they said was a sudden shift in enforcing a longstanding dress code.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Gunmen in Aleppo, Firing at Ambulances, Stall Latest Evacuation Effort
item.media:description: Buses waited to evacuate civilians and insurgent fighters from rebel-held parts of eastern Aleppo, Syria, on Thursday.
item.description: One person was killed and several others were wounded in the Syrian city as they were being transported to Red Cross vehicles, opposition figures said.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Taiwan Is Both Exhilarated and Unnerved by Trump’s China Remarks
item.media:description: Lin Fei-fan, a protest leader, in Taipei, Taiwan. He is excited by President-elect Donald J. Trump’s apparent willingness to rethink the One China policy, but also anxious: “We are suspicious of his motivations.”
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect’s apparent willingness to rethink the principle that prioritizes China over Taiwan has energized many, but some fear being used as a bargaining chip.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and AMY QIN

item.title: Miss World Contestant Who Challenged China Is Allowed to Speak Once More
item.media:description: Anastasia Lin, Canada’s Miss World entrant, spoke out about murky, government-sanctioned organ transplant programs in China.
item.description: Pageant organizers gave Anastasia Lin permission on Wednesday to speak to the news media, ending a three-week standoff over her criticism of human rights abuses in China.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte on Killing Criminal Suspects: ‘I Used to Do It Personally’
item.description: “I was really looking for a confrontation, so I could kill,” President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines told business leaders at a meeting in Manila.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: French Terrorism Suspects Appeared Anything But
item.media:description: A bus stop in the Meinau neighborhood of Strasbourg, France. The area, along with the city’s Neuhof section, has yielded major terrorism arrests.
item.media:credit: Benjamin Kilb for The New York Times
item.description: France is unsettled by the arrests of four men, suspected of planning terrorist activities, who showed no sign of radicalization.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Ruling Paves Way for Transfer of Art Trove Including Nazi-Looted Works
item.media:description: Some of the roughly 1,500 artworks Cornelius Gurlitt kept for years in his Munich apartment.
item.media:credit: Staatsanwaltschaft Augsburg, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The German owner of the 1,500 artworks was of sound mind when he bequeathed them to a museum in Switzerland, a court in Munich ruled.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and ALISON SMALE

item.title: Bishop Javier Echevarría, Leader of Opus Dei, Dies at 84
item.media:description: Bishop Javier Echevarría in Rome in 2008.
item.description: Bishop Echevarría was the prelate of Opus Dei, the disciplined and influential global Roman Catholic organization, since 1994.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Trump Firm Quits Brazil Hotel Project That Was Named in Criminal Inquiry
item.media:description: The Trump Hotel Rio de Janeiro. A spokeswoman for Trump Hotels said that the decision to pull out of the project was made because of problems in completing the luxury property.
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.description: The hotel and another Trump venture in the city had been named in a federal investigation over investments by public pension fund managers in commercial projects.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Calçoene Journal: A ‘Stonehenge,’ and a Mystery, in the Amazon
item.media:description: Calçoene pottery at the Amapá State Scientific and Technological Research Institute in Macapá, Brazil.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: The conventional belief is that only small tribes could have inhabited the Amazon jungle, but new discoveries call that into question.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: What in the World: For Dissidents, a Phone Hack to Foil Spying Eyes: Cover the Camera
item.media:description: Some potential targets fight back against phone hackers with a simple countermeasure: a sticker or a patch of masking tape over the camera lens.
item.media:credit: Simone Mudde and Olivier van Breugel
item.description: Authoritarian governments can change a trusted device into a surveillance tool, but some potential targets have found a simple way to fight back.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARNEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Don’t Call It ‘Smog’ in Beijing, Call It a ‘Meteorological Disaster’
item.media:description: A woman wore a mask against air pollution in Beijing on Monday.
item.description: City officials are poised to legally classify air pollution as a weather calamity, like a sandstorm, worrying those who see it as a way to dodge responsibility.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: A Hotline for Americans and Russians to Avoid Catastrophe in Syrian Skies
item.media:description: A Russian Sukhoi Su-34 fighter-bomber released bombs over Syria in August. The united States and Russia use a hotline to communicate and avoid any disasters in the skies over Syria.
item.description: American and Russian officers talk three times a week to “deconflict,” military jargon for an effort to call ahead to avoid disaster in the skies over Syria.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Harsh Facebook Posts, Jail and Now Death: A Man’s Fate Angers Algeria
item.description: The country’s government is coming under criticism after the death of a journalist imprisoned under a new law that criminalizes offending the president.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Italian Parliament Approves New Government, for Now
item.description: Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni won the support of both houses this week, but political debate has danced around one question: How long will it last?
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: To Protect Civilians, Pentagon Tightens Rules on Combat
item.description: The changes are the second time this year that the Defense Department has modified its Law of War Manual in response to criticism that portions were inaccurate or dangerous.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Museum Pieces on Loan From Crimea Belong to Ukraine, Dutch Court Rules
item.media:description: The exhibition “Crimea: Gold and Secrets of the Black Sea” at the Allard Pierson Museum in Amsterdam in 2014.
item.description: More than 500 artifacts lent to a museum in the Netherlands before the Russian takeover of Crimea will be sent to a museum in Kiev, not back to the disputed peninsula.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: In Major Step for Drone Delivery, Amazon Flies Package to Customer in England
item.media:description: Amazon made its first commercial drone delivery on Dec. 7 in Cambridgeshire, England.
item.description: Jeff Bezos announced on Twitter that his company had made its first automated shipment, a two-mile, 13-minute trip to a shopper in Cambridgeshire.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD and MARK SCOTT

item.title: Sinosphere: For China’s State Media, Trump Victory Can’t Cure ‘American Disease’
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump in Wisconsin on Tuesday. Chinese state news outlets have argued that the United States election demonstrated why one-party rule is right for China.
item.description: A stream of articles in Communist Party publications has argued that the election of Donald J. Trump has showed the United States to be dysfunctional and dissolute.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Convicted of Sodomy, Malaysian Opposition Leader Loses Bid for Freedom
item.description: Anwar Ibrahim, the jailed opposition leader, had hoped for a decision that would let him run against the scandal-ridden prime minister in a coming election.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: No Change in U.S. Commitment to Asia-Pacific Under Trump, Admiral Says
item.media:description: Admiral Harris has been an outspoken critic of China’s expansion in the South China Sea, where it has built artificial islands and military installations in the Spratly archipelago, including Fiery Cross Reef, above.
item.description: “You can count on America now and into the future,” Adm. Harry B. Harris Jr., head of the United States Pacific Command, said Wednesday in Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Sinosphere: For Taiwan, a Dilemma Over Identity, Economy and China
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan addressed naval officers in July, about two months after she took office. Some fear Ms. Tsai’s recent phone call with President-elect Donald J. Trump will destabilize United States-China relations, while others see a welcome rethinking of Washington’s ties to Taiwan.
item.media:credit: Office of The President Taiwan, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Syaru Shirley Lin, a political economist, discusses Donald J. Trump’s break with protocol in talking to Taiwan, and Taiwan’s ambivalence toward economic integration with China.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Only a Rumbling Volcano Could Make North Korea and the West Play Nice
item.media:description: Mount Paektu, on the border between North Korea and China, erupted 1,000 years ago in one of the most violent volcanic explosions in human history.
item.description: Mount Paektu is sacred to the North Korean people. When a swarm of tiny earthquakes were recorded, the reclusive country decided it needed help.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: No, Settlers Don’t Control Israeli Politics
item.media:description: An Israeli family in the Jewish settlement Amona in the West Bank this month.
item.description: If they did, why would the government be preparing to evacuate a hilltop outpost in the West Bank?
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Islam Gets Second-Class Status in Germany
item.media:description: A mosque in Berlin during the annual Open Mosque Day in October.
item.description: There are 4.3 million Muslims in the country, yet their faith is legally nonexistent.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER GÖRLACH

item.title: Editorial: Donald Trump’s Denial About Russia
item.media:description: Donald Trump last week in Iowa.
item.description: Mr. Trump’s rejection of the United States’ probe into Russian hacking of the 2016 election leaves him isolated.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
